title: Legislative Council Question No.18 (Written Reply)
question_text:
Date of Sitting: 29 November 2000 Asked by: Hon LAU Kong-wah
Replied by: Secretary for Health and Welfare Question : It was reported that the Food and Drug Administration ("FDA") of the United States had decided to legislate against the use of phenylpropanolamine in drugs.  In this connection, will the Government inform this Council: (a) of the drugs containing phenylpropanolamine which are being sold in Hong Kong; the side-effects of such drugs on people, and whether relevant indications are marked on the package of such drugs;

of such drugs on people, and whether relevant indications are marked on the package of such drugs; (b) whether any reports have been received over the past three years concerning the side-effects of these drugs on people; and (c) whether the Administration will make reference to the relevant study report of the FDA and consider legislating against the sale of such drugs; if not, of the reasons for that?
reply_text:
Madam President, (a) Pharmaceutical products containing phenylpropanolamine (PPA) have been available
for more than 20 years.  There are currently about 200 registered
pharmaceutical products containing phenylpropanolamine.  PPA has been known
to cause a rise in blood pressure.  In a recent study conducted by US
scientists, an increased risk of haemorrhagic stroke (internal bleeding of the
brain) among women using PPA was detected.  PPA is currently controlled as

brain) among women using PPA was detected.  PPA is currently controlled as
a Part I poison under the Pharmacy and Poisons Ordinance, which means that all
pharmaceutical products containing it must be sold by authorized sellers of
poisons (i.e. dispensaries) under the supervision of a registered pharmacist. 
Moreover, products containing PPA on sale in Hong Kong must carry the statement,
in both English and Chinese, on the label or in the package insert that �If
you are under the care of your doctor or receiving continual prescribed

you are under the care of your doctor or receiving continual prescribed
medication or are pregnant then consult your doctor.�. (b) The Department of Health (DH) has not received any report of adverse reactions
arising from the use of pharmaceutical products containing PPA in the past three
years. (c) The Registration Committee of the Pharmacy and Poisons Board (PPB) considered the
side effects of PPA, including the findings of the USA report, at its meeting on
24.11.2000.  The Committee concluded that the association of PPA with

24.11.2000.  The Committee concluded that the association of PPA with
haemorrhagic stroke is significant only when PPA is used in appetite suppressant
products, the use of which is often on a long-term basis.  Accordingly, the
Committee decided to deregister all such products, namely �  Bolarmine Capsule Diet-B Capsule Slimonin Capsule DH has informed the manufacturers of the three products of the Committee's decision, which
will take effect on December 23, 2000 (at the lapse of the 4-week statutory

period for the lodgement of an appeal against the decision, if any). 
Meanwhile, these manufacturers are requested to immediately recall the three
products from dispensaries and doctor's clinics, and the public is advised to
cease using them and to consult their doctor or pharmacists for alternative
treatment. The Registration Committee has also recommended to the PPB that the control of
cough-and-cold remedies containing PPA should be tightened by upgrading them
from Part I to Part I First Schedule poisons.  This means that every time a

from Part I to Part I First Schedule poisons.  This means that every time a
pharmacist sells such products, he must make a record of the sale, sign it and
ask the customer to sign also.  Subject to PPB's decision, the relevant
amendment regulation on these additional control measures will be submitted to
the Legislative Council for approval. In addition, the Registration Committee has decided that labelling of these remedies should
also be revised to limit the dosage to no more than 100 mg daily. 
Manufacturers are also required to strengthen the warning section in the product

Manufacturers are also required to strengthen the warning section in the product
literature, including not using the product as an appetite suppressant; advising
patients with high blood pressure hyperthyroidism, heart disease or who are
receiving monoamine oxidase inhibitors not to use these products; and that these
products may aggravate conditions such as diabetes, glaucoma or prostatic
enlargement.  Manufacturers are given a grace period of two months to
effect the necessary changes.
